ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In this course, we developed skills of close reading and analysis, and thought about familiar themes and concepts through a novel analytical lens. We also learned strategies for writing annotated bibliographies and research papers.
I developed my writing skills and learned to close read and analyze literature and journal articles.
I learned how to formulate a strong argument, as well as how to structure and conduct a solid research paper.

I learned how to become a more efficient writer and engage with both traditional texts as well as other forms of media to construct and defend an argument. I also learned how to compose a formal research paper, which is of utmost importance at a research university.

I learned to critically analyze both text and media sources that discussed the high school experience from various perspectives. I was able to then use this analysis to develop my argumentative writing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course did a really great job of offering engaging material that challenged students to think critically about the course topic.

Seamus makes the class very fun! I loved the open environment that he created to discuss our high school experiences, and I found much of the class content to be enjoyable. The class does start out a little slow because of the reading you have to go through, but Seamus makes the class worth it in the end.

This course is incredibly engaging, but it started off a bit slow at first with the amount of readings compared to other sources of media (e.g., movies and musical soundtracks). However, as the course continued it got increasingly engaging. The feedback given by the professor was also incredibly helpful!

This was my absolute favorite class of the semester. We talked about the high school experience from so many different perspectives both through readings and media. The small class size made it really engaging and I loved hearing everyone's perspectives and different high school experiences. Seamus is amazing - so supportive, helpful, enthusiastic, and the class wouldn't have been the same without him. If I had to think of a weakness, it would be that sometimes there wasn't a lot of participation during discussions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course worked well over Zoom and I genuinely feel as though the new medium was used to the course's advantage.

The discussions were very helpful and engaging, and I loved participating in the weekly talks that are planned out. I think a little more guidance during the talks about the readings could be helpful.
The implementation of check-in questions was very useful in helping create an environment that didnt feel monotonous.

I think this class successfully transitioned towards the online format. I also think the small class size allowed for sustained engagement. We had a lot of group discussions as well as smaller breakout rooms, which I think were very engaging and effective.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course! Seamus was very helpful and engaging throughout the entire writing process, and the course provided lots of interesting material to consider.
Yes! If you like to listen to other people's experiences or share your own, this is the class for you because it gives you a chance to reflect back on high school and see how it has impacted you.
100%. I gained a deeper appreciation for analysis, and it was so interesting to have topics discussed in an intro-level English seminar applied to a topic that I was passionate about (high school!).

Yes. I would recommend this course to anyone who has a love for both classic depictions of high school as well as anyone who is fond of their own high school years. This course does an excellent job of both presenting a wide variety of experiences and helps analyze ones own experience within the spectrum of experiences.

Absolutely. I loved this course not only because I learned to improve my reading, analyzing, and writing skills, but also because the theme of the class is something that everyone has their own experiences and perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
N/A
N/A

ENGL 114 04
        What Even Was High School?
